displayed_text: Family Member 1: And so like, now when he starts chemo or whatever and if he gets nauseous, I call M____? Doctor: Exactly. Yep. And you know, we'll make sure you have your prescription or whatever. Well, hopefully we'll have to give it to you so that, you know, when people run into trouble, it's always at 2 AM in the morning, right? Family Member 1: Right? Doctor: When you're like, “Uh oh, nowhere to go and no one to call.” So, first of all, you'll have that in your medicine cabinet. We'll make sure you have your nausea medication, because that's usually the thing that runs into trouble. You know, if you have diarrhea or constipation, that's over the counter that you can get, go to any 24 hour pharmacy for that. Family Member 1: Okay, yeah. Doctor: But things that are nausea medicines require prescriptions. Family Member 1: Do you do Zofran? Doctor: We do Zofran and we do Compazine. And then depending on the level of how much nausea you know. Family Member 1: Zofran works for me. I got pneumonia. Doctor: Well, you're right. And I think the important part here is that this is not a big nausea, type of chemo. There are some where you're like, “Okay, brace yourself, it's going to happen.” This is pretty mild. Patient: Okay. Doctor: It's actually called a mild emetogenic. So it just means it’s not gonna make you puke, but everybody's different.

Patient: Okay. So (clears throat) Doctor: Uh usually they’ve told us a turn-around of one week after they get it Patient: Okay. Doctor: so I would say by a couple of weeks we should know. Patient: Alright. So are you needing more blood today or you already have enough blood? Yes. Yeah. Doctor: Now for this study you have to come back within ten days or so from today to get uh do the endo study stuff. Patient: Okay. Okay. Doctor: So I was hoping at that point if we have some answers for you we can even get… Family Member: Mm, even get started. Doctor: … start anticipating and making some decisions about the other thing. Okay? Family Member: Okay. Patient: That’ll work. Doctor: So I was gonna say you should sign the pre-screening consent if that’s okay with you and send the blood test out.

Patient: So, that’s good news that we can travel. I like being able to see the grandkids you know. Doctor: Yeah, yeah, and they’ll tell you exactly when and how long, you know, the kids, exposure, all of that he will explain. But we will start with giving you a side effects sheet and then I’ll have J____ come in and just tell J____, our nurse, Patient: Yeah, right. Doctor: about what to expect and how she’s going to do the prior authorization and then well we’ll kick you to the curb. Okay? Patient: Okay. Sounds good. Doctor: We’ll get out next one for I think it’s two months from now maybe for the shot. Family Member: Yeah. It will be the time for the Lupron. Doctor: Yes. We’ll see you guys back next time. Family Member: Congrats on your award. I see that J____ posted that. Doctor: Thank you. Patient: Thank you so much. Doctor: Alright, we’ll see you. Patient: Okay.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the last 3 years (2 years but les: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the last 3 years (2 years but less than 3 years ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.1 time: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::1 time

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.disagree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::disagree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.neutral: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::neutral

A doctor would never mislead you about a.disagree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::disagree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.neutral: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::neutral

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.agree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::agree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.agree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::agree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.agree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::agree

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.College graduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::College graduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.Yes, Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::Yes, Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.White: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::White

displayed_text: Patient: They didn’t tell me anything about it yet. I see Dr. G___ next week. Doctor: And you’re still taking the Enzalutamide? Patient: What’s that? Doctor: The Xtandi. Patient: Yes, I am, yes. Four pills a day. Doctor: Anything else you want to tell me about how you feel? Patient: I feel pretty good. Doctor: Hospitalized? Patient: No. Doctor: And you’re here today because you had a follow-up or other reasons? Patient: For a follow-up, yeah, yeah. They took blood last time, and ran some protocols and you were going to check on some numbers. Doctor: Anything new on your body that you’ve noticed that you want me to take a look at? Patient: No. Well some swelling. (pause and ruffling sounds)

Patient: Okay. Doctor: So I think he’s mentioned in his note a standard option for you go to would be to chemotherapy. So chemotherapy in someone like you after hormones haven’t worked well enough or long enough; Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: chemotherapy shrinks the PSA for a while, shrinks the tumor for a while in about forty/fifty percent of people. So almost half the people get some benefit from chemotherapy. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: We usually know after three or four cycles as to whether or not it’s gonna help, and we keep going. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: We also sort of know what side effects you’re going to experience to sort of see whether you can tolerate this. We have to adjust the doses about that. So that’s an approved drug that’s known to extend survival if people get the drugs, tolerate the drugs, respond to the drugs. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: You know those people can do well compared to those who don’t respond or don’t get the drug. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So chemo would be something that you know it could be given here, it could be given there, but it’s standard treatment.

Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: That also tells you about chemo. Patient: Right. Doctor: The vitamin C part would only be done here. Patient: Right. Doctor: And, so, that would be, letting you go through that process to sort of say, “Okay. That’s the more traditional next step.” Um. The other one is a window phase one. Is that you have therapy, you’re not ready to go to chemotherapy, I’m willing to try something under our observations with blood tests and scans. That if the cancer would sort of wildly changing, we abort and do chemotherapy. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Umm. So, that would be sort of, in some ways, a gamble. But, some folks, everything we know about the drugs you’ve had so far, we’ve had people gamble at one point. Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: And, then, the third one is we draw blood tests today, just to see the AR-V7 positive. That maybe that you say in what you’re doing now, and if you are AR-V7 positive, then we can sort of say, “Hey, yeah, let’s look at this other option,” if the immune therapy would be something that you would think about. Patient: Okay. What, what, what’s the, uh, uh, um likelihood of, of, if at that time the AR-V7, uh, testing comes back negative which means I can’t do that. Doctor: Right.

Patient: B___. Family Member: B___. Doctor: And you got it the same day you saw me or you got, you went over there earlier today or-? Family Member: He got it done here today. They made an appointment here today. Doctor: Okay. Huh, but normally you go to B___? Family Member: Yes. Patient: Yeah. Yeah. I had the blood test done this morning. Is that what we were reading off for the PSA this morning? Doctor: Yep. Yeah. You might give me a little bit longer than two weeks since you don’t go to Medicare, huh, until, huh, Friday. Family Member: Right. Patient: Yeah. March first it kicks in. I’ve got the card on me if you need it. Family Member: I’ve also got that, our insurance too. Doctor: Okay. So I just emailed the pharmacist to let them know what we’re thinking, huh, to get you started, that’s you’ve switched to Medicare, and that they might end up looking next week. Huh, so hopefully, in the next week or two we’ll know where you are.

Patient: Right, okay. Doctor: So again, since you’re not eligible for that at this point in time - Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: A minimum PSA for that trial has to be above one. Patient: Okay. Doctor: One point zero. But just to prepare for the future – Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: I wanted to have that conversation with you. Patient: Uh hum. Sure. And this is the PSA level; you’re also saying we need to see something on the CT scan, right? Doctor: Correct. So for this particular trial, if the cancer is invisible, which will become non-metastatic. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: You would not be eligible. So it just has to do with; this trial is designed for a specific subset of patients so that cancer has to be both metastatic and hormone-resistant.

Family Member: Try something else. Doctor: Okay? Patient: Okay. Doctor: Makes sense? Patient: Okay. Family Member: We stand, we stand in agreement with you. Doctor: Okay. But the good news is that you’re feeling well and the bone disease really did not get any worse. Family Member: Right. That’s good. Doctor: You know? You didn’t have any new areas, nothing else. Family Member: That’s a blessing. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Yeah. Your pain and everything else overall is pretty well controlled.

Healthcare Professional: Thirty days, I do believe. From the, um, the, the Doctor: From the hormone first Healthcare Professional: hormone first. Doctor: Right, so if he gets this hormone therapy on the twenty-first, then Healthcare Professional: On the twenty-first, then he could. December. Probably, uh, we could stretch it out to the end of December. Doctor: Okay. Healthcare Professional: Yeah. We can get you started. Family Member: What are the pills? Doctor: Uh, the pills are bicalutamide. So, basically, they, uh, block, uh, your cancer cell from using testosterone that’s in your body. So, right away, they start treating your cancer. Uh. But, when I give you your shot, uh, the testosterone shoots up. It could make your cancer worse in that few days. And, so, I wanna protect that surge of testosterone that occurs when we give you the first shot. Patient: Hmmm. Family Member: The first shot of the hormone? Doctor: The first shot of the hormones.

Patient: Yeah. Yeah. Doctor: How’s your hot flashes? Patient: They come out all the time. (Laughs) Doctor: And urine. Any trouble passing your water? Patient: Uh-uh. Doctor: Okay. And they didn’t keep you in the hospital. Anything new since I saw you a couple of weeks ago that you want to tell me about? Patient: No. Doctor: No? Patient: No. Doctor: Then why did I bring you back? Patient: You said I have to change, huh, some treatment. Doctor: Let me see what I’ve got here. So you’ve got pain. Let’s put that there. Okay. Any other bumps or lumps that you’ve noted? Any rashes, skin changes?

Patient: Okay. Doctor: So with the Percocet you’re actually going lower on the dose of the OxyContin. Patient: Okay. Doctor: You’re okay with that? Patient: Okay. What you think? Doctor: Well I don’t think it’s going to be all that much better for you, but if you think so I’m willing to give it a try instead of the Norco. Patient: Okay well I’m with you. Doctor: Keep taking the OxyContin in the morning and in the evening. Patient: Right. That’s what I do. Doctor: Don’t change that. Patient: That’s what I do. Doctor: Okay and then instead of the Norco you use the Percocet. Patient: Okay.

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Oxycodone immediate release five milligrams. Patient: No, that’s been set up for ten milligrams, and that’s as needed now after it’s been about two weeks since my radiation. Doctor: So it’s that ten milligram pill you take? Patient: No it’s two fives. Doctor: Oh, yeah. The OxyContin? And the OxyContin is thirty milligrams twice a day? Patient: Once a day; I’m taking it once a day now. Doctor: Once a day. Patient: Yeah, I’m taking it at night, so you know to get ahead of the pain. But it’s been pretty good. I haven’t been in much hip pain lately, hardly at all. Doctor: The Simvastatin twenty milligrams a day. That’s your Zocor. Patient: Yeah, right. Doctor: Your Flomax or Tamsulosin once a day? Patient: Yeah.

Patient: Got to find out if we… Doctor: Exactly. Patient: We got to find out. Doctor: So, you guys now are on the same page as me in terms of what to expect after the scans. Patient: Okay. Doctor: I never order stuff when it’s, I don’t want it to be a mystery. You guys should know exactly what we’re going to do depending on the results. Patient: Okay. I like that. Doctor: Yeah, so we have a plan either Patient: Okay. Doctor: way and I’ll, you know, continue to sort of work through this Patient: Okay. Doctor: . Now, in the meantime, I don’t like you in pain and I think that having a small dose of narcotics like Norco Patient: Okay.

Patient: That’s why I’m always like at that time when I was low or no pain and that’s why he was thinking that’s what we… Doctor: Yeah, Yes, that would have been. Yeah. Patient: Okay. I understand that now. Doctor: So, like back then would have been or if we get you stable and kind of quiet and good we could always redo it, Patient: We can still. Okay. Okay. Doctor: Right. So, it’s not off the table forever. It’s just at this moment it’s not. Patient: At this moment, I understand that, okay. Doctor: Good. Family Member: I have one more question. Doctor: Yeah, go ahead. Family Member: Because he, when we last saw Dr. V____ in Vegas in July he was telling us there’s some research but it will be seven or eight months out. So that was July so it wouldn’t be until like next month about combining radium with the docetaxel. Doctor: Yeah, yeah, so that’s already actually in trial. It is… Family Member: He thought it was better for the body.
